001package squidpony.squidgrid.mapping;
002
003import squidpony.squidgrid.Direction;
004import squidpony.squidmath.Coord;
005import squidpony.squidmath.IRNG;
006import squidpony.squidmath.IntVLA;
007import squidpony.squidmath.OrderedSet;
008import squidpony.squidmath.PoissonDisk;
009import squidpony.squidmath.VanDerCorputQRNG;
010import squidpony.squidmath.WeightedTable;
011
012import java.util.ArrayList;
013import java.util.Arrays;
014import java.util.List;
015import java.util.Map;
016
017/**
018 * A dungeon generator that can use a mix of techniques to have part-cave, part-room dungeons. Not entirely intended for
019 * normal use outside of this library, though it can be very useful when you want to make a dungeon match a specific
020 * path and existing generators that use MixedGenerator aren't sufficient. You may want to use a simpler generator based
021 * on this, like SerpentMapGenerator, which generates a long, winding path that loops around on itself. This supports
022 * the getEnvironment() method, which can be used in conjunction with RoomFinder to find where separate room, corridor,
023 * and cave areas have been placed.
024 * <br>
025 * Based on Michael Patraw's excellent Drunkard's Walk dungeon generator.
026 * http://mpatraw.github.io/libdrunkard/
027 * @see squidpony.squidgrid.mapping.SerpentMapGenerator a normal use for MixedGenerator that makes winding dungeons
028 * @see squidpony.squidgrid.mapping.SerpentDeepMapGenerator uses MixedGenerator as it makes a multi-level dungeon
029 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 10/22/2015.
030 */
031public class MixedGenerator implements IDungeonGenerator {     
032    public static final int CAVE = 0,
033        BOX = 1,
034        ROUND = 2,
035        BOX_WALLED = 3,
036        ROUND_WALLED = 4;
037
038    /**
039     * Constant for environment tiles that are not near a cave, room, or corridor. Value is 0.
040     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
041     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#UNTOUCHED}.
042     */
043    public static final int UNTOUCHED = 0;
044    /**
045     * Constant for environment tiles that are floors for a room. Value is 1.
046     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
047     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#ROOM_FLOOR}.
048     */
049    public static final int ROOM_FLOOR = 1;
050    /**
051     * Constant for environment tiles that are walls near a room. Value is 2.
052     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
053     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#ROOM_WALL}.
054     */
055    public static final int ROOM_WALL = 2;
056    /**
057     * Constant for environment tiles that are floors for a cave. Value is 3.
058     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
059     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#CAVE_FLOOR}.
060     */
061    public static final int CAVE_FLOOR = 3;
062    /**
063     * Constant for environment tiles that are walls near a cave. Value is 4.
064     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
065     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#CAVE_WALL}.
066     */
067    public static final int CAVE_WALL = 4;
068    /**
069     * Constant for environment tiles that are floors for a corridor. Value is 5.
070     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
071     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#CORRIDOR_FLOOR}.
072     */
073    public static final int CORRIDOR_FLOOR = 5;
074    /**
075     * Constant for environment tiles that are walls near a corridor. Value is 6.
076     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
077     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#CORRIDOR_WALL}.
078     */
079    public static final int CORRIDOR_WALL = 6;
080
081    //protected EnumMap<CarverType, Integer> carvers;
082    protected double[] carvers;
083    protected WeightedTable carverTable;
084    protected int width, height;
085    protected float roomWidth, roomHeight;
086    public IRNG rng;
087    protected char[][] dungeon;
088    protected boolean generated;
089    protected int[][] environment;
090    protected boolean[][] marked, walled, fixedRooms;
091    protected IntVLA points;
092    protected int totalPoints;
093
094    /**
095     * Mainly for internal use; this is used by {@link #MixedGenerator(int, int, IRNG)} to get its room positions.
096     * This is (and was) the default for generating a List of Coord if no other collection of Coord was supplied to the
097     * constructor. For some time this was not the default, and {@link #cleanPoints(int, int, IRNG)} was used instead.
098     * Both are still options, but this technique seems to keep corridors shorter and makes connections between rooms
099     * more relevant to the current area.
100     * <br>
101     * <a href="https://gist.githubusercontent.com/tommyettinger/be0ed51858cb492bc7e8cda43a04def1/raw/dae9d8e4f45dd3a3577bdd5f58b419ea5f9ed570/PoissonDungeon.txt">Preview map.</a>
102     * @param width dungeon width in cells
103     * @param height dungeon height in cells
104     * @param rng rng to use
105     * @return evenly spaced Coord points in a list made by PoissonDisk, trimmed down so they aren't all used
106     * @see PoissonDisk used to make the list
107     */
108    public static OrderedSet<Coord> basicPoints(int width, int height, IRNG rng)
109    {
110        return PoissonDisk.sampleRectangle(Coord.get(2, 2), Coord.get(width - 3, height - 3),
111                8.5f * (width + height) / 120f, width, height, 35, rng);
112    }
113    /**
114     * Mainly for internal use; this was used by {@link #MixedGenerator(int, int, IRNG)} to get its room positions, and
115     * you can choose to use it with {@code new MixedGenerator(width, height, rng, cleanPoints(width, height, rng))}.
116     * It produces a fairly rigid layout of rooms that should have less overlap between rooms and corridors; the
117     * downside to this is that corridors can become extremely long. The exact technique used here is to get points from
118     * a Halton-like sequence, formed using {@link VanDerCorputQRNG} to get a van der Corput sequence, for the x axis
119     * and a scrambled van der Corput sequence for the y axis. MixedGenerator will connect these points in pairs. The
120     * current method is much better at avoiding "clumps" of closely-positioned rooms in the center of the map.
121     * <br>
122     * <a href="https://gist.githubusercontent.com/tommyettinger/2745e6fc16fc2acebe2fc959fb4e4c2e/raw/77e1f4dbc844d8892c1a686754535c02cadaa270/TenDungeons.txt">Preview maps, with and without box drawing characters.</a>
123     * Note that one of the dungeons in that gist was produced as a fallback by {@link DungeonGenerator} with no
124     * arguments (using DEFAULT_DUNGEON as the dungeon style), because the map this method produced in one case had too
125     * few floor cells to be used.
126     * @param width dungeon width in cells; must be at least 3 because the edges will be walls
127     * @param height dungeon height in cells; must be at least 3 because the edges will be walls
128     * @param rng IRNG to use, such as an RNG, StatefulRNG, or GWTRNG
129     * @return erratically-positioned but generally separated Coord points to pass to a MixedGenerator constructor
130     * @see VanDerCorputQRNG used to get separated positions
131     */
132    public static List<Coord> cleanPoints(int width, int height, IRNG rng)
133    {
134        width -= 2;
135        height -= 2;
136        //float mx = rng.nextFloat() * 0.2f, my = rng.nextFloat() * 0.2f;
137        int sz = width * height * 3 + 255 >>> 8,
138                seed = rng.next(9);
139        //System.out.println("mx: " + mx + ", my: " + my + ", index: " + index);
140        List<Coord> list = new ArrayList<>(sz);
141        for (int i = 0; i < sz; i++) {
142            list.add(VanDerCorputQRNG.roberts(width, height, 1, 1, i + seed));
143        }
144//        for (int i = 0; i < blocks; i++) {
145//            Coord area = VanDerCorputQRNG.roberts(width * 3 >> 2, height * 3 >> 2, 1, 1, i + seed);
146//            for (int j = 0; j < 5; j++) {
147//                list.add(VanDerCorputQRNG.roberts(width >> 2, height >> 2, area.x, area.y, index++ + seed2));
148//            }
149//        }
150        return list;
151    }
152
153    /**
154     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given RNG.
155     * This version of the constructor uses a sub-random point sequence to generate the points it will draw caves and
156     * corridors between, helping to ensure a minimum distance between points, but it does not ensure that paths between
157     * points  will avoid overlapping with rooms or other paths. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect
158     * what the dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to
159     * only caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
160     * @param width the width of the final map in cells
161     * @param height the height of the final map in cells
162     * @param rng an RNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
163     * @see PoissonDisk used to ensure spacing for the points.
164     */
165    public MixedGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng) {
166        this(width, height, rng, cleanPoints(width, height, rng));
167    }
168
169    /**
170     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given RNG.
171     * This version of the constructor uses a List of Coord points from some other source to determine the path to add
172     * rooms or caves to and then connect. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect what the
173     * dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to only
174     * caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
175     * @param width the width of the final map in cells
176     * @param height the height of the final map in cells
177     * @param rng an RNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
178     * @param sequence a List of Coord to connect in order; index 0 is the start, index size() - 1 is the end.
179     * @see SerpentMapGenerator a class that uses this technique
180     */
181    public MixedGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng, List<Coord> sequence) {
182        this.width = width;
183        this.height = height;
184        this.roomWidth = width / 64.0f;
185        this.roomHeight = height / 64.0f;
186        if(width <= 2 || height <= 2)
187            throw new IllegalStateException("width and height must be greater than 2");
188        this.rng = rng;
189        dungeon = new char[width][height];
190        environment = new int[width][height];
191        marked = new boolean[width][height];
192        walled = new boolean[width][height];
193        fixedRooms = new boolean[width][height];
194        Arrays.fill(dungeon[0], '#');
195        Arrays.fill(environment[0], DungeonUtility.UNTOUCHED);
196        for (int i = 1; i < width; i++) {
197            System.arraycopy(dungeon[0], 0, dungeon[i], 0, height);
198            System.arraycopy(environment[0], 0, environment[i], 0, height);
199        }
200        totalPoints = sequence.size() - 1;
201        points = new IntVLA(totalPoints);
202        for (int i = 0; i < totalPoints; i++) {
203            Coord c1 = sequence.get(i), c2 = sequence.get(i + 1);
204            points.add(((c1.x & 0xff) << 24) | ((c1.y & 0xff) << 16) | ((c2.x & 0xff) << 8) | (c2.y & 0xff));
205        }
206        carvers = new double[5];
207    }
208    /**
209     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given IRNG.
210     * This version of the constructor uses a Map with Coord keys and Coord array values to determine a
211     * branching path for the dungeon to take; each key will connect once to each of the Coords in its value, and you
212     * usually don't want to connect in both directions. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect what the
213     * dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to only
214     * caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
215     * @param width the width of the final map in cells
216     * @param height the height of the final map in cells
217     * @param rng an IRNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
218     * @param connections a Map of Coord keys to arrays of Coord to connect to next; shouldn't connect both ways
219     * @see SerpentMapGenerator a class that uses this technique
220     */
221    public MixedGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng, Map<Coord, List<Coord>> connections)
222    {
223        this(width, height, rng, connections, 0.8f);
224    }
225    /**
226     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given IRNG.
227     * This version of the constructor uses a Map with Coord keys and Coord array values to determine a
228     * branching path for the dungeon to take; each key will connect once to each of the Coords in its value, and you
229     * usually don't want to connect in both directions. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect what the
230     * dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to only
231     * caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
232     * @param width the width of the final map in cells
233     * @param height the height of the final map in cells
234     * @param rng an IRNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
235     * @param connections a Map of Coord keys to arrays of Coord to connect to next; shouldn't connect both ways
236     * @param roomSizeMultiplier a float multiplier that will be applied to each room's width and height
237     * @see SerpentMapGenerator a class that uses this technique
238     */
239    public MixedGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng, Map<Coord, List<Coord>> connections,
240                          float roomSizeMultiplier) {
241        this.width = width;
242        this.height = height;
243        roomWidth = (width / 64.0f) * roomSizeMultiplier;
244        roomHeight = (height / 64.0f) * roomSizeMultiplier;
245        if(width <= 2 || height <= 2)
246            throw new IllegalStateException("width and height must be greater than 2");
247        this.rng = rng;
248        dungeon = new char[width][height];
249        environment = new int[width][height];
250        marked = new boolean[width][height];
251        walled = new boolean[width][height];
252        fixedRooms = new boolean[width][height];
253        Arrays.fill(dungeon[0], '#');
254        Arrays.fill(environment[0], DungeonUtility.UNTOUCHED);
255        for (int i = 1; i < width; i++) {
256            System.arraycopy(dungeon[0], 0, dungeon[i], 0, height);
257            System.arraycopy(environment[0], 0, environment[i], 0, height);
258        }
259        totalPoints = 0;
260        for(List<Coord> vals : connections.values())
261        {
262            totalPoints += vals.size();
263        }
264        points = new IntVLA(totalPoints);
265        for (Map.Entry<Coord, List<Coord>> kv : connections.entrySet()) {
266            Coord c1 = kv.getKey();
267            for (Coord c2 : kv.getValue()) {
268                points.add(((c1.x & 0xff) << 24) | ((c1.y & 0xff) << 16) | ((c2.x & 0xff) << 8) | (c2.y & 0xff));
269            }
270        }
271        carvers = new double[5];
272    }
273    
274    /**
275     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create caves from one room to the next. If count is 0 or less, no caves
276     * will be made. If count is at least 1, caves are possible, and higher numbers relative to the other carvers make
277     * caves more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used, then repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically
278     * about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10
279     * between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), putRoundRoomCarvers(), putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(), and
280     * putWalledRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
281     * @param count the number of carvers making caves between rooms; only matters in relation to other carvers
282     */
283    public void putCaveCarvers(int count)
284    {
285        carvers[CAVE] = count;
286    }
287    /**
288     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
289     * with a random size in a box shape at the start and end, and a small room at the corner if there is one. If count
290     * is 0 or less, no box-shaped rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, box-shaped rooms are possible, and higher
291     * numbers relative to the other carvers make box-shaped rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used, then
292     * repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
293     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
294     * putRoundRoomCarvers(), putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(), and putWalledRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
295     * @param count the number of carvers making box-shaped rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
296     *              to other carvers
297     */
298    public void putBoxRoomCarvers(int count)
299    {
300        carvers[BOX] = count;
301    }
302
303    /**
304     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
305     * with a random size in a circle shape at the start and end, and a small circular room at the corner if there is
306     * one. If count is 0 or less, no circular rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, circular rooms are possible,
307     * and higher numbers relative to the other carvers make circular rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used,
308     * then repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
309     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
310     * putRoundRoomCarvers(), putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(), and putWalledRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
311     * @param count the number of carvers making circular rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
312     *              to other carvers
313     */
314    public void putRoundRoomCarvers(int count)
315    {
316        carvers[ROUND] = count;
317    }
318    /**
319     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
320     * with a random size in a box shape at the start and end, and a small room at the corner if there is one, enforcing
321     * the presence of walls around the rooms even if another room is already there or would be placed there. Corridors
322     * can always pass through enforced walls, but caves will open at most one cell in the wall. If count
323     * is 0 or less, no box-shaped rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, box-shaped rooms are possible, and higher
324     * numbers relative to the other carvers make box-shaped rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used, then
325     * repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
326     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
327     * putRoundRoomCarvers(), putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(), and putWalledRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
328     * @param count the number of carvers making box-shaped rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
329     *              to other carvers
330     */
331    public void putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(int count)
332    {
333        carvers[BOX_WALLED] = count;
334    }
335
336    /**
337     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
338     * with a random size in a circle shape at the start and end, and a small circular room at the corner if there is
339     * one, enforcing the presence of walls around the rooms even if another room is already there or would be placed
340     * there. Corridors can always pass through enforced walls, but caves will open at most one cell in the wall. If
341     * count is 0 or less, no circular rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, circular rooms are possible,
342     * and higher numbers relative to the other carvers make circular rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used,
343     * then repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
344     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
345     * putRoundRoomCarvers(), putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(), and putWalledRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
346     * @param count the number of carvers making circular rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
347     *              to other carvers
348     */
349    public void putWalledRoundRoomCarvers(int count)
350    {
351        carvers[ROUND_WALLED] = count;
352    }
353
354    /**
355     * Uses the added carvers (or just makes caves if none were added) to carve from point to point in sequence, if it
356     * was provided by the constructor, or evenly-spaced randomized points if it was not. This will never carve out
357     * cells on the very edge of the map. Uses the numbers of the various kinds of carver that were added relative to
358     * each other to determine how frequently to use a given carver type.
359     * @return a char[][] where '#' is a wall and '.' is a floor or corridor; x first y second
360     */
361    public char[][] generate()
362    {
363        if(carvers[0] <= 0 && carvers[1] <= 0 && carvers[2] <= 0 && carvers[3] <= 0 && carvers[4] <= 0)
364            carvers[0] = 1;
365        carverTable = new WeightedTable(carvers);
366//        CarverType[] carvings = carvers.keySet().toArray(new CarverType[carvers.size()]);
367//        int[] carvingsCounters = new int[carvings.length];
368//        int totalLength = 0;
369//        for (int i = 0; i < carvings.length; i++) {
370//            carvingsCounters[i] = carvers.get(carvings[i]);
371//            totalLength += carvingsCounters[i];
372//        }
373//        CarverType[] allCarvings = new CarverType[totalLength];
374//
375//        for (int i = 0, c = 0; i < carvings.length; i++) {
376//            for (int j = 0; j < carvingsCounters[i]; j++) {
377//                allCarvings[c++] = carvings[i];
378//            }
379//        }
380//        if(allCarvings.length == 0)
381//        {
382//            allCarvings = new CarverType[]{CarverType.CAVE};
383//            totalLength = 1;
384//        }
385//        else
386//            allCarvings = rng.shuffle(allCarvings, new CarverType[allCarvings.length]);
387
388        for (int p = 0; p < totalPoints; p++) {
389            int pair = points.get(p);
390            Coord start = Coord.get(pair >>> 24 & 0xff, pair >>> 16 & 0xff),
391                  end   = Coord.get(pair >>> 8 & 0xff, pair & 0xff);
392            int ct = carverTable.random(rng.nextLong());
393            Direction dir;
394            switch (ct)
395            {
396                case CAVE:
397                    markPiercing(end);
398                    markEnvironmentCave(end.x, end.y);
399                    store();
400                    double weight = 0.75;
401                    do {
402                        Coord cent = markPlusCave(start);
403                        if(cent != null)
404                        {
405                            markPiercingCave(cent);
406                            markPiercingCave(cent.translate(1, 0));
407                            markPiercingCave(cent.translate(-1, 0));
408                            markPiercingCave(cent.translate(0, 1));
409                            markPiercingCave(cent.translate(0, -1));
410                            weight = 0.95;
411                        }
412                        dir = stepWobbly(start, end, weight);
413                        start = start.translate(dir);
414                    }while (dir != Direction.NONE);
415                    break;
416                case BOX:
417                    markRectangle(end, rng.between(1, 5), rng.between(1, 5));
418                    markRectangle(start, rng.between(1, 4), rng.between(1, 4));
419                    store();
420                    dir = Direction.getDirection(end.x - start.x, end.y - start.y);
421                    if(dir.isDiagonal())
422                        dir = rng.nextBoolean() ? Direction.getCardinalDirection(dir.deltaX, 0)
423                                : Direction.getCardinalDirection(0, dir.deltaY);
424                    while (start.x != end.x && start.y != end.y)
425                    {
426                        markPiercing(start);
427                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
428                        start = start.translate(dir);
429                    }
430                    markRectangle(start, 1, 1);
431                    dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(end.x - start.x, (end.y - start.y));
432                    while (!(start.x == end.x && start.y == end.y))
433                    {
434                        markPiercing(start);
435                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
436                        start = start.translate(dir);
437                    }
438                    break;
439                case BOX_WALLED:
440                    markRectangleWalled(end, rng.between(1, 5), rng.between(1, 5));
441                    markRectangleWalled(start, rng.between(1, 4), rng.between(1, 4));
442                    store();
443                    dir = Direction.getDirection(end.x - start.x, end.y - start.y);
444                    if(dir.isDiagonal())
445                        dir = rng.nextBoolean() ? Direction.getCardinalDirection(dir.deltaX, 0)
446                                : Direction.getCardinalDirection(0, dir.deltaY);
447                    while (start.x != end.x && start.y != end.y)
448                    {
449                        markPiercing(start);
450                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
451                        start = start.translate(dir);
452                    }
453                    markRectangleWalled(start, 1, 1);
454                    dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(end.x - start.x, (end.y - start.y));
455                    while (!(start.x == end.x && start.y == end.y))
456                    {
457                        markPiercing(start);
458                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
459                        start = start.translate(dir);
460                    }
461                    break;
462                case ROUND:
463                    markCircle(end, rng.between(2, 6));
464                    markCircle(start, rng.between(2, 6));
465                    store();
466                    dir = Direction.getDirection(end.x - start.x, end.y - start.y);
467                    if(dir.isDiagonal())
468                        dir = rng.nextBoolean() ? Direction.getCardinalDirection(dir.deltaX, 0)
469                                : Direction.getCardinalDirection(0, dir.deltaY);
470                    while (start.x != end.x && start.y != end.y)
471                    {
472                        markPiercing(start);
473                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
474                        start = start.translate(dir);
475                    }
476                    markCircle(start, 2);
477                    dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(end.x - start.x, (end.y - start.y));
478                    while (!(start.x == end.x && start.y == end.y))
479                    {
480                        markPiercing(start);
481                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
482                        start = start.translate(dir);
483                    }
484                    break;
485                case ROUND_WALLED:
486                    markCircleWalled(end, rng.between(2, 6));
487                    markCircleWalled(start, rng.between(2, 6));
488                    store();
489                    dir = Direction.getDirection(end.x - start.x, end.y - start.y);
490                    if(dir.isDiagonal())
491                        dir = rng.nextBoolean() ? Direction.getCardinalDirection(dir.deltaX, 0)
492                                : Direction.getCardinalDirection(0, dir.deltaY);
493                    while (start.x != end.x && start.y != end.y)
494                    {
495                        markPiercing(start);
496                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
497                        start = start.translate(dir);
498                    }
499                    markCircleWalled(start, 2);
500                    dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(end.x - start.x, (end.y - start.y));
501                    while (!(start.x == end.x && start.y == end.y))
502                    {
503                        markPiercing(start);
504                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
505                        start = start.translate(dir);
506                    }
507                    break;
508            }
509            store();
510        }
511        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
512            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
513                if(fixedRooms[x][y])
514                    markPiercingCave(Coord.get(x, y)); // this is only used by LanesMapGenerator, where caves make sense
515            }
516        }
517        store();
518        markEnvironmentWalls();
519        generated = true;
520        return dungeon;
521    }
522
523    public char[][] getDungeon() {
524        return dungeon;
525    }
526
527    public int[][] getEnvironment()
528    {
529        return environment;
530    }
531
532    public boolean hasGenerated()
533    {
534        return generated;
535    }
536
537    public boolean[][] getFixedRooms() {
538        return fixedRooms;
539    }
540
541    public void setFixedRooms(boolean[][] fixedRooms) {
542        this.fixedRooms = fixedRooms;
543    }
544
545    /**
546     * Internal use. Takes cells that have been previously marked and permanently stores them as floors in the dungeon.
547     */
548    protected void store()
549    {
550        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
551            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
552                if(marked[i][j])
553                {
554                    dungeon[i][j] = '.';
555                    marked[i][j] = false;
556                }
557            }
558        }
559    }
560
561    /**
562     * Internal use. Finds all floor cells by environment and marks untouched adjacent (8-way) cells as walls, using the
563     * appropriate type for the nearby floor.
564     */
565    protected void markEnvironmentWalls()
566    {
567        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
568            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
569                if(environment[i][j] == DungeonUtility.UNTOUCHED)
570                {
571                    boolean allWalls = true;
572                    //lowest precedence, also checks for any floors
573                    for (int x = Math.max(0, i - 1); x <= Math.min(width - 1, i + 1); x++) {
574
575                        for (int y = Math.max(0, j - 1); y <= Math.min(height - 1, j + 1); y++) {
576                            if (environment[x][y] == DungeonUtility.CORRIDOR_FLOOR) {
577                                markEnvironment(i, j, DungeonUtility.CORRIDOR_WALL);
578                            }
579                            if(dungeon[x][y] == '.')
580                                allWalls = false;
581                        }
582                    }
583                    //if there are no floors we don't need to check twice again.
584                    if(allWalls)
585                        continue;
586                    //more precedence
587                    for (int x = Math.max(0, i - 1); x <= Math.min(width - 1, i + 1); x++) {
588
589                        for (int y = Math.max(0, j - 1); y <= Math.min(height - 1, j + 1); y++) {
590                            if (environment[x][y] == DungeonUtility.CAVE_FLOOR) {
591                                markEnvironment(i, j, DungeonUtility.CAVE_WALL);
592                            }
593                        }
594                    }
595                    //highest precedence
596                    for (int x = Math.max(0, i - 1); x <= Math.min(width - 1, i + 1); x++) {
597
598                        for (int y = Math.max(0, j - 1); y <= Math.min(height - 1, j + 1); y++) {
599                            if (environment[x][y] == DungeonUtility.ROOM_FLOOR) {
600                                markEnvironment(i, j, DungeonUtility.ROOM_WALL);
601                            }
602                        }
603                    }
604
605                }
606            }
607        }
608    }
609
610    /**
611     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor.
612     * @param x x position to mark
613     * @param y y position to mark
614     * @return false if everything is normal, true if and only if this failed to mark because the position is walled
615     */
616    protected boolean mark(int x, int y) {
617        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1 && !walled[x][y]) {
618            marked[x][y] = true;
619            return false;
620        }
621        else return x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1 && walled[x][y];
622    }
623
624    /**
625     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor.
626     * @param x x position to mark
627     * @param y y position to mark
628     */
629    protected void markPiercing(int x, int y) {
630        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1) {
631            marked[x][y] = true;
632        }
633    }
634    /**
635     * Internal use. Marks a point's environment type as the appropriate kind of environment.
636     * @param x x position to mark
637     * @param y y position to mark
638     * @param kind an int that should be one of the constants in MixedGenerator for environment types.
639     */
640    protected void markEnvironment(int x, int y, int kind) {
641        environment[x][y] = kind;
642    }
643
644    /**
645     * Internal use. Marks a point's environment type as a corridor floor.
646     * @param x x position to mark
647     * @param y y position to mark
648     */
649    protected void markEnvironmentCorridor(int x, int y) {
650        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1 && environment[x][y] != DungeonUtility.ROOM_FLOOR && environment[x][y] != DungeonUtility.CAVE_FLOOR) {
651            markEnvironment(x, y, DungeonUtility.CORRIDOR_FLOOR);
652        }
653    }
654
655    /**
656     * Internal use. Marks a point's environment type as a room floor.
657     * @param x x position to mark
658     * @param y y position to mark
659     */
660    protected void markEnvironmentRoom(int x, int y) {
661        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1) {
662            markEnvironment(x, y, DungeonUtility.ROOM_FLOOR);
663        }
664    }
665
666    /**
667     * Internal use. Marks a point's environment type as a cave floor.
668     * @param x x position to mark
669     * @param y y position to mark
670     */
671    protected void markEnvironmentCave(int x, int y) {
672        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1 && environment[x][y] != DungeonUtility.ROOM_FLOOR) {
673            markEnvironment(x, y, DungeonUtility.CAVE_FLOOR);
674        }
675    }
676    /**
677     * Internal use. Marks a point to be considered a hard wall.
678     * @param x x position to mark
679     * @param y y position to mark
680     */
681    protected void wallOff(int x, int y) {
682        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1) {
683            walled[x][y] = true;
684        }
685    }
686
687    /**
688     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor.
689     * @param pos position to mark
690     * @return false if everything is normal, true if and only if this failed to mark because the position is walled
691     */
692    protected boolean mark(Coord pos)
693    {
694        return mark(pos.x, pos.y);
695    }
696
697    /**
698     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor, piercing walls.
699     * @param pos position to mark
700     */
701    protected void markPiercing(Coord pos)
702    {
703        markPiercing(pos.x, pos.y);
704    }
705    /**
706     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor, piercing walls, and also marks the point as a cave floor.
707     * @param pos position to mark
708     */
709    protected void markPiercingCave(Coord pos)
710    {
711        markPiercing(pos.x, pos.y);
712        markEnvironmentCave(pos.x, pos.y);
713    }
714    /**
715     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor, piercing walls, and also marks the point as a room floor.
716     * @param x x coordinate of position to mark
717     * @param y y coordinate of position to mark
718     */
719    protected void markPiercingRoom(int x, int y)
720    {
721        markPiercing(x, y);
722        markEnvironmentRoom(x, y);
723    }
724
725    /**
726     * Internal use. Marks a point and the four cells orthogonally adjacent to it.
727     * @param pos center position to mark
728     * @return null if the center of the plus shape wasn't blocked by wall, otherwise the Coord of the center
729     */
730    private Coord markPlus(Coord pos) {
731        Coord block = null;
732        if (mark(pos.x, pos.y))
733            block = pos;
734        mark(pos.x + 1, pos.y);
735        mark(pos.x - 1, pos.y);
736        mark(pos.x, pos.y + 1);
737        mark(pos.x, pos.y - 1);
738        return block;
739    }
740
741    /**
742     * Internal use. Marks a point and the four cells orthogonally adjacent to it, and also marks any cells that weren't
743     * blocked as cave floors.
744     * @param pos center position to mark
745     * @return null if the center of the plus shape wasn't blocked by wall, otherwise the Coord of the center
746     */
747    private Coord markPlusCave(Coord pos) {
748        Coord block = null;
749        if (mark(pos.x, pos.y))
750            block = pos;
751        else
752            markEnvironmentCave(pos.x, pos.y);
753        if(!mark(pos.x + 1, pos.y))
754            markEnvironmentCave(pos.x + 1, pos.y);
755        if(!mark(pos.x - 1, pos.y))
756            markEnvironmentCave(pos.x - 1, pos.y);
757        if(!mark(pos.x, pos.y + 1))
758            markEnvironmentCave(pos.x, pos.y + 1);
759        if(!mark(pos.x, pos.y - 1))
760            markEnvironmentCave(pos.x, pos.y - 1);
761        return block;
762    }
763    /**
764     * Internal use. Marks a rectangle of points centered on pos, extending halfWidth in both x directions and
765     * halfHeight in both vertical directions. Marks all cells in the rectangle as room floors.
766     * @param pos center position to mark
767     * @param halfWidth the distance from the center to extend horizontally
768     * @param halfHeight the distance from the center to extend vertically
769     * @return null if no points in the rectangle were blocked by walls, otherwise a Coord blocked by a wall
770     */
771    private Coord markRectangle(Coord pos, int halfWidth, int halfHeight)
772    {
773        halfWidth = Math.max(1, Math.round(halfWidth * roomWidth));
774        halfHeight = Math.max(1, Math.round(halfHeight * roomHeight));
775        Coord block = null;
776        for (int i = pos.x - halfWidth; i <= pos.x + halfWidth; i++) {
777            for (int j = pos.y - halfHeight; j <= pos.y + halfHeight; j++) {
778                if(mark(i, j))
779                    block = Coord.get(i, j);
780                else
781                    markEnvironmentRoom(i, j);
782            }
783        }
784        return block;
785    }
786    /**
787     * Internal use. Marks a rectangle of points centered on pos, extending halfWidth in both x directions and
788     * halfHeight in both vertical directions. Also considers the area just beyond each wall, but not corners, to be
789     * a blocking wall that can only be passed by corridors and small cave openings. Marks all cells in the rectangle as
790     * room floors.
791     * @param pos center position to mark
792     * @param halfWidth the distance from the center to extend horizontally
793     * @param halfHeight the distance from the center to extend vertically
794     * @return null if no points in the rectangle were blocked by walls, otherwise a Coord blocked by a wall
795     */
796    private Coord markRectangleWalled(Coord pos, int halfWidth, int halfHeight)
797    {
798        halfWidth = Math.max(1, Math.round(halfWidth * roomWidth));
799        halfHeight = Math.max(1, Math.round(halfHeight * roomHeight));
800        Coord block = null;
801        for (int i = pos.x - halfWidth; i <= pos.x + halfWidth; i++) {
802            for (int j = pos.y - halfHeight; j <= pos.y + halfHeight; j++) {
803                markPiercing(i, j);
804                markEnvironmentRoom(i, j);
805            }
806        }
807        for (int i = Math.max(0, pos.x - halfWidth - 1); i <= Math.min(width - 1, pos.x + halfWidth + 1); i++) {
808            for (int j = Math.max(0, pos.y - halfHeight - 1); j <= Math.min(height - 1, pos.y + halfHeight + 1); j++)
809            {
810                wallOff(i, j);
811            }
812        }
813        return null;
814    }
815
816    /**
817     * Internal use. Marks a circle of points centered on pos, extending out to radius in Euclidean measurement. Marks
818     * all cells in the circle as room floors.
819     * @param pos center position to mark
820     * @param radius radius to extend in all directions from center
821     * @return null if no points in the circle were blocked by walls, otherwise a Coord blocked by a wall
822     */
823    private Coord markCircle(Coord pos, int radius)
824    {
825        Coord block = null;
826        int high;
827        radius = Math.max(1, Math.round(radius * Math.min(roomWidth, roomHeight)));
828        for (int dx = -radius; dx <= radius; ++dx)
829        {
830            high = (int)Math.floor(Math.sqrt(radius * radius - dx * dx));
831            for (int dy = -high; dy <= high; ++dy)
832            {
833                if(mark(pos.x + dx, pos.y + dy))
834                    block = pos.translate(dx, dy);
835                else
836                    markEnvironmentRoom(pos.x + dx, pos.y + dy);
837            }
838        }
839        return block;
840    }
841    /**
842     * Internal use. Marks a circle of points centered on pos, extending out to radius in Euclidean measurement.
843     * Also considers the area just beyond each wall, but not corners, to be a blocking wall that can only be passed by
844     * corridors and small cave openings. Marks all cells in the circle as room floors.
845     * @param pos center position to mark
846     * @param radius radius to extend in all directions from center
847     * @return null if no points in the circle were blocked by walls, otherwise a Coord blocked by a wall
848     */
849    private Coord markCircleWalled(Coord pos, int radius)
850    {
851        Coord block = null;
852        int high;
853        radius = Math.max(1, Math.round(radius * Math.min(roomWidth, roomHeight)));
854        for (int dx = -radius; dx <= radius; ++dx)
855        {
856            high = (int)Math.floor(Math.sqrt(radius * radius - dx * dx));
857            for (int dy = -high; dy <= high; ++dy)
858            {
859                markPiercing(pos.x + dx, pos.y + dy);
860                markEnvironmentRoom(pos.x + dx, pos.y + dy);
861            }
862        }
863        for (int dx = -radius; dx <= radius; ++dx)
864        {
865            high = (int)Math.floor(Math.sqrt(radius * radius - dx * dx));
866            int dx2 = Math.max(1, Math.min(pos.x + dx, width - 2));
867            for (int dy = -high; dy <= high; ++dy)
868            {
869                int dy2 = Math.max(1, Math.min(pos.y + dy, height - 2));
870
871                wallOff(dx2, dy2-1);
872                wallOff(dx2+1, dy2-1);
873                wallOff(dx2-1, dy2-1);
874                wallOff(dx2, dy2);
875                wallOff(dx2+1, dy2);
876                wallOff(dx2-1, dy2);
877                wallOff(dx2, dy2+1);
878                wallOff(dx2+1, dy2+1);
879                wallOff(dx2-1, dy2+1);
880
881            }
882        }
883        return null;
884    }
885
886    /**
887     * Internal use. Drunkard's walk algorithm, single step. Based on Michael Patraw's C code, used for cave carving.
888     * http://mpatraw.github.io/libdrunkard/
889     * @param current the current point
890     * @param target the point to wobble towards
891     * @param weight between 0.5 and 1.0, usually. 0.6 makes very random caves, 0.9 is almost a straight line.
892     * @return a Direction, either UP, DOWN, LEFT, or RIGHT if we should move, or NONE if we have reached our target
893     */
894    private Direction stepWobbly(Coord current, Coord target, double weight)
895    {
896        int dx = target.x - current.x;
897        int dy = target.y - current.y;
898
899        if (dx >  1) dx = 1;
900        if (dx < -1) dx = -1;
901        if (dy >  1) dy = 1;
902        if (dy < -1) dy = -1;
903
904        double r = rng.nextDouble();
905        Direction dir;
906        if (dx == 0 && dy == 0)
907        {
908            return Direction.NONE;
909        }
910        else if (dx == 0 || dy == 0)
911        {
912            int dx2 = (dx == 0) ? dx : dy, dy2 = (dx == 0) ? dy : dx;
913            if (r >= (weight * 0.5))
914            {
915                r -= weight * 0.5;
916                if (r < weight * (1.0 / 6) + (1 - weight) * (1.0 / 3))
917                {
918                    dx2 = -1;
919                    dy2 = 0;
920                }
921                else if (r < weight * (2.0 / 6) + (1 - weight) * (2.0 / 3))
922                {
923                    dx2 = 1;
924                    dy2 = 0;
925                }
926                else
927                {
928                    dx2 = 0;
929                    dy2 *= -1;
930                }
931            }
932            dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(dx2, dy2);
933
934        }
935        else
936        {
937            if (r < weight * 0.5)
938            {
939                dy = 0;
940            }
941            else if (r < weight)
942            {
943                dx = 0;
944            }
945            else if (r < weight + (1 - weight) * 0.5)
946            {
947                dx *= -1;
948                dy = 0;
949            }
950            else
951            {
952                dx = 0;
953                dy *= -1;
954            }
955            dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(dx, dy);
956        }
957        if(current.x + dir.deltaX <= 0 || current.x + dir.deltaX >= width - 1) {
958            if (current.y < target.y) dir = Direction.DOWN;
959            else if (current.y > target.y) dir = Direction.UP;
960        }
961        else if(current.y + dir.deltaY <= 0 || current.y + dir.deltaY >= height - 1) {
962            if (current.x < target.x) dir = Direction.RIGHT;
963            else if (current.x > target.x) dir = Direction.LEFT;
964        }
965        return dir;
966    }
967
968}
